document_data.name: Pasocada Basin
document_data.mainbody: The '''Pasocada Basin''' was a harsh land far north of the rest of [[Maztica]], with which it had very little contact. It was, accordingly, very different both culturally and environmentally.

Notable Locations.Pasocada River: A massive river that drained much of the Pasocada Basin before emptying into the western ocean.
Notable Locations.[[Long Canyon]]: A ninety-mile (145 km) long canyon carved by the Pasocada River. It ranged between one mile (1.6 km) and ten miles (16 km) in width, and was home to a tribe of [[hill giant]]s .
Notable Locations.[[Esh Alakar]]: A group of mysterious ruins in the Long Canyon. They were avoided by travelers, but the similarly-built and nearby [[Bridge of the Ancients]] was widely used.
Notable Locations.The [[Black Mesa]]: A large mesa with plentiful coal deposits visible as black striations on its sides. The Azuposi sometimes burned the coal during special rituals.
Notable Locations.[[Dunobo Springs]]: A group of small springs located in the forested foothills of the mountains. During the spring, the small streams fed by the springs turned into the Danozi Wash that were responsible for creating the Sun Canyon. The Azuposi often cut down trees from around the springs.
Notable Locations.The [[Sun Canyon]]: Carved by the Danozi Wash, the Sun Canyon was an important locations to the Azuposi, for it was the spiritual heart of the Azuposi nation. In addition, the city of Michaca was located in it.
Notable Locations.[[Michaca]]: Also called the City of Gold, it was the largest settlement in the Pasocada Basin.
Notable Locations.[[Growling Falls]]: A 200-foot (61-meter) tall waterfall. The noise it made was believed to be the growling of monstrous bear fiend imprisoned there. Because the bear was the child of a god who had assumed an animal form, it could not be killed. It once threatened the land until it was defeated by a hero that the Azuposi called Hinchapa and the Dog People called Incholcpa.

document_data.Inhabitants:
The Pasocada Basin was home to [[humans]] and [[Poscadar elf|elves]], called Poscadar elves. There were three different human cultures: the agrarian [[Azuposi]], the coastal [[Metahel]], and the nomadic [[Nahopaca]].

In addition, tribes of [[Dog People]] and two clans of [[Desert dwarf|desert dwarves]] lived in the nearby regions of the [[Sands of Itzcala]] desert.
